message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory values show hypercalcemia, which can lead to acute renal failure. The X-ray and lab results also indicate multiple myeloma as the cause of his symptoms. Amyloidosis can also cause renal dysfunction, but it is less common in multiple myeloma. Infiltration of the kidney by malignant cells is a possibility in multiple myeloma, but hypercalcemia is the more common cause of acute renal failure. NSAIDs are not a likely cause of acute renal failure in this patient's case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's serum calcium level is high, indicating hypercalcemia. This condition can lead to acute renal failure due to the deposition of calcium in the kidney tubules. Amyloid deposits and infiltration of the kidney by malignant cells can also cause acute renal failure, but they are not the most common cause in this scenario. NSAIDs do not cause acute renal failure in patients with normal renal function.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic website for help. The patient presents with severe lower back pain and fatigue, with an osteolytic lesion in the 1st lumbar vertebra and several similar lesions in the pelvic bone. The serum calcium level is elevated, suggesting hypercalcemia, which is a common cause of acute renal condition in patients with bone cancer. Amyloid deposits and infiltration of the kidney by malignant cells may cause renal damage as well, but are less common in this specific case. NSAIDs are unlikely to cause acute renal failure in this case.
